NumLoopy¶

Numloopy is an array library whose syntax for array computations is NumPy-like, and generates Loopy kernels. The loopy kernels can then be translated to various backends:

  • OpenCL
  • CUDA
  • ISPC
  • Plain C

In order to fully understand the transformation model of NumLoopy, it is strongly advised be familiar with loopy’s semantics.

The following example is included in the numloopy distribution as examples/hello-numloopy.py.

import numloopy as nplp
import loopy as lp

np = nplp.begin_computation_stack()

a = np.ones(10)
b = np.arange(10)
c = 2*a + 3*b

knl = np.end_computation_stack([a, c])
print(lp.generate_code_v2(knl).device_code())

When the above script is run, the following kernel is generated:

__kernel void __attribute__ ((reqd_work_group_size(1, 1, 1))) loopy_kernel(__global double *__restrict__ arr, __global double *__restrict__ arr_0)
{
  for (int i_4 = 0; i_4 <= 9; ++i_4)
    arr[i_4] = 1.0;
  for (int i_5 = 0; i_5 <= 9; ++i_5)
    arr_0[i_5] = arr[i_5] * 2.0 + i_5 * 3.0;
}

Lazy Evaluation¶

The variables which are of interest at the end of the computation must be passed to evaluate argument of the numloopy.Stack.end_computation_stack(). All other variables are substituted as expression into the computations. Thereby, only lazily evaluating the specified variables.

Transformation model of NumLoopy¶

The transformation information can be obtained by passing True for the transform argument to numloopy.Stack.end_computation_stack(). The transformations data is returned as a mapping from the name of the variables involved to the tuple of inames involved in their corresponding assignments. The following example gives an example of the transformation.

import numloopy as nplp
import loopy as lp

np = nplp.begin_computation_stack()

a = np.ones((4, 4, 4))
b = np.argument((4, 4, 4)) # indicates that this would be available later
c = 2*a + 3*b

knl, tf_data = np.end_computation_stack([c], transform=True)  # indicates to get the transform data

UNROLLED_LOOP = 0 # '0' for innermost loop, should be '2' for the outermost loop
transformed_knl = lp.tag_inames(knl,
        {tf_data[c.name][UNROLLED_LOOP]: "unr"})
print(lp.generate_code_v2(transformed_knl).device_code()) # print the generated code

And when the above script is run, the generated code is

__kernel void __attribute__ ((reqd_work_group_size(1, 1, 1))) loopy_kernel(__global double const *__restrict__ arr, __global double *__restrict__ arr_0)
{
  for (int i_16 = 0; i_16 <= 3; ++i_16)
    for (int i_15 = 0; i_15 <= 3; ++i_15)
    {
      arr_0[4 * i_15 + i_16] = 2.0 + arr[4 * i_15 + i_16] * 3.0;
      arr_0[16 + 4 * i_15 + i_16] = 2.0 + arr[16 + 4 * i_15 + i_16] * 3.0;
      arr_0[32 + 4 * i_15 + i_16] = 2.0 + arr[32 + 4 * i_15 + i_16] * 3.0;
      arr_0[48 + 4 * i_15 + i_16] = 2.0 + arr[48 + 4 * i_15 + i_16] * 3.0;
    }
}

The same code with UNROLLED_LOOP=2 (outermost loop is unrolled) generates

__kernel void __attribute__ ((reqd_work_group_size(1, 1, 1))) loopy_kernel(__global double const *__restrict__ arr, __global double *__restrict__ arr_0)
{
  for (int i_15 = 0; i_15 <= 3; ++i_15)
    for (int i_14 = 0; i_14 <= 3; ++i_14)
      arr_0[16 * i_14 + 4 * i_15] = 2.0 + arr[16 * i_14 + 4 * i_15] * 3.0;
  for (int i_15 = 0; i_15 <= 3; ++i_15)
    for (int i_14 = 0; i_14 <= 3; ++i_14)
      arr_0[1 + 16 * i_14 + 4 * i_15] = 2.0 + arr[1 + 16 * i_14 + 4 * i_15] * 3.0;
  for (int i_15 = 0; i_15 <= 3; ++i_15)
    for (int i_14 = 0; i_14 <= 3; ++i_14)
      arr_0[2 + 16 * i_14 + 4 * i_15] = 2.0 + arr[2 + 16 * i_14 + 4 * i_15] * 3.0;
  for (int i_15 = 0; i_15 <= 3; ++i_15)
    for (int i_14 = 0; i_14 <= 3; ++i_14)
      arr_0[3 + 16 * i_14 + 4 * i_15] = 2.0 + arr[3 + 16 * i_14 + 4 * i_15] * 3.0;
}
